stream_context.summary: Kaze works on level design and asset creation for a retro-futuristic space level (Course 15), building out platforming paths with unique objects like a gramophone with piano-key stairs and a flying parking lot. He also discusses plans for a potential Steam release, debugs hardware-specific crashes, and begins modeling a new CRT TV asset based on a contributor's design.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning a potential commercial release of the game on Steam. This would be achieved by using a static recompiler and replacing all Nintendo IP to create a standalone PC game.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking maybe using the static recompilation to release this game both like as an n64 game with Mario and officially as like a game on Steam.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes the hub world is the most critical component of a 3D platformer and plans to develop it last to ensure it is perfectly designed and integrates all the levels and secrets effectively.
development_findings.quote: The hub world is I think the only reason Mario 64 was famous, popular. If Mario 64 hadn't had a hub world, I don't think anyone would have liked the game.

development_findings.summary: While designing a path up a large gramophone object, Kaze devised a creative solution to build a staircase directly into the model's geometry, which he then decided to texture like piano keys.
development_findings.quote: Wait, I kind of love that idea. That's just the type of schizophrenic thinking you need to be in a game.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the project is to preserve the player's freedom of movement and avoid mechanics that are overly restrictive or take control away from the player.
development_findings.quote: I don't like to take the base Mario 64 movement away from the player too much.

development_findings.summary: Player feedback from a beta test on a modified dive mechanic was crucial. The initial change was 'hated,' leading to an iteration where players can change direction but lose speed, which was much better received.
The project is undergoing a visual upgrade, with contributor Bruno Gadsen providing a new, more detailed retro-futuristic model for the CRT TVs that will replace the old one.

Kaze encountered a hardware-specific crash caused by an excessive number of collision triangles in an area, a bug that did not appear on Project 64 but did on real hardware and more accurate emulators.
The team has a process where Kaze will create video analyses of courses before Biobak begins his artistic and design rework of them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is hesitant to use Kickstarter for funding due to concerns and a lack of understanding about how sales tax laws apply, fearing significant financial repercussions.
context_findings.quote: I'm scared of using Kickstarter and because of sales tax loss. I don't understand how they work with Kickstarter and I'm kind of scared of getting completely fucked.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is cautious about accepting help from new artists because the time required to teach them the technical limitations and specific workflows for N64 development often outweighs their potential contribution.
context_findings.quote: I'm a little worried. I'm gonna have to spend so much time teaching him that he ends up costing more time than he saves, you know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally isolated himself during university to focus entirely on his work, an experience he acknowledges was detrimental to his mental health and does not recommend to others.
context_findings.quote: I had like the loneliest possible college experience. And I wanted it that way... That is not good for your mental health. And I don't recommend anyone does that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the large file sizes of modern games are a result of developers optimizing for development cost and speed rather than for game performance or storage efficiency.
context_findings.quote: They're not optimizing the games, like graphics or whatever, they're optimizing the cost to develop games. They're min-mixing money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is a German citizen residing in Canada and mentioned he will be eligible to take the Canadian citizenship test in about five months.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided critical design feedback on a boss concept, identifying it as potentially confusing for players and proposing a more direct and understandable alternative involving the boss attacking from black holes.
biobak.quote: I was talking to Biobak about the Yoshi boss idea that we had and maybe wanted to make into the game and I agree with what he said about it being maybe a little cryptic and he brought up a few other ideas that maybe we're going to do.

biobak.summary: Biobak is actively reworking the art and design for Course 2 as part of the project's ongoing graphical overhaul.

zeina.summary: Zeina has contributed concept art for the Shy Guy NPCs that will appear in the game.
zeina.quote: They're going to be shy guys. Zayna already drew something for them.

zeina.summary: As Kaze's wife, Zeina actively supports his work, demonstrated by gifting a significant number of memberships during the stream.

key_stories.title: Planning a Commercial Steam Release
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlined a strategy to release the game commercially on Steam. This involves using static recompilation to create a PC build and systematically replacing all of Nintendo's intellectual property, including character models, code, and sound, to avoid legal issues.
key_stories.challenge: How to release the game to a wider audience and potentially monetize it without infringing on Nintendo's copyright.
key_stories.process: The plan is to use the existing decompilation project's static recompiler. All Nintendo assets, from Mario's model and movement code to sound engine components, would be stripped out and replaced with original creations.
key_stories.outcome: This creates a viable, though labor-intensive, path to an independent, commercial release on platforms like Steam, completely separate from the N64 ROM hack.
key_stories.key_quote: Obviously, I would replace all Nintendo assets and would kick out the last bit of Nintendo code as well. I'm not just going to release a Mario game on Steam. That would literally be insanity.

key_stories.title: Collaborative Boss Redesign
key_stories.summary: An initial concept for a major boss was deemed too cryptic. After discussing it with graphics artist Biobak, the team pivoted to a new, more direct design based on his feedback.
key_stories.challenge: An initial boss fight concept was at risk of being too confusing or unintuitive for players.
key_stories.process: Kaze presented the idea to Biobak, who identified that it might be 'a little cryptic.' Biobak then proposed an alternative where the boss attacks from black holes with tentacles and its face, and the player must jump into its mouth to attack internal weak points.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze and the team agreed with Biobak's assessment and adopted the new, more understandable boss mechanic, demonstrating a healthy collaborative process.
key_stories.key_quote: I was talking to Biobak about the Yoshi boss idea... and I agree with what he said about it being maybe a little cryptic and he brought up a few other ideas that maybe we're going to do.

key_stories.title: Player Feedback on Dive Mechanic
key_stories.summary: Kaze attempted to change Mario's dive to be more 'realistic' by removing mid-air direction control, but beta testers strongly disliked it. This led to a compromise that balanced the original feel with a new penalty, demonstrating a feedback-driven design process.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to alter a core movement mechanic (the dive), but his initial change was strongly rejected by players.
key_stories.process: The first change, which locked the dive's direction, was put into a beta test. After receiving overwhelmingly negative feedback, Kaze created a second version that allows players to change direction but at the cost of losing all forward momentum.
key_stories.outcome: The new compromise was well-received by the community, proving to be a successful iteration that respected player expectations while still introducing a new gameplay nuance.
key_stories.key_quote: People are like twice as mad if you take it away than if they had never had it.
